snippet.textDisplay:
Early in 2015 the LG G4 was released and was arguably one of LG's best efforts. In comparison of what Samsung is expected to release in the S20 Ultra the difference is MASSIVE in only a short five year span.

LG G4 : Samsung Galaxy S20 Ultra

LTE-A (2CA) Cat6 300/50 Mbps : LTE-A (7CA) Cat20 2000/150 Mbps, 5G
Gorilla Glass 3/plastic : Gorilla Glass 6/stainless steel
5.5 inches/IPS LCD : 6.9 inches/Dynamic AMOLED
72.5% screen/body : 90.6% screen/body
Android 5 : Android 10
Snapdragon 808 : Snapdragon 865
LG UX 4 : One UI 2
24-bit/192kHz audio : 32-bit/384kHz audio
32GB/3GB RAM : 512GB/16GB RAM
16 MP/8 MP selfie : 108 MP, 48 MP telephoto (10X optical zoom), 12 MP ultrawide, TOF 3D/40 MP selfie
Li-Ion3000 mAh : Li-Po 5000 mAh
18W charging : 45W charging, 15W wireless, 9W reverse wireless
3.5mm jack : IP68, Samsung Pay, HDR10+, Samsung DeX, Always On, 120Hz, Super Steady video, dual video rec./call, USB C, Ultrasonic under display fingerprint reader, natural language commands, AKG tuned Dual Speakers
snippet.textOriginal:
Early in 2015 the LG G4 was released and was arguably one of LG's best efforts. In comparison of what Samsung is expected to release in the S20 Ultra the difference is MASSIVE in only a short five year span.

LTE-A (2CA) Cat6 300/50 Mbps  :  LTE-A (7CA) Cat20 2000/150 Mbps, 5G

snippet.textDisplay: Exactly.. yes.. but no 😂 Improve battery life on some models and quite frankly your average person won’t upgrade for at least 3-4 years. Besides that, the Phone is quite possibly at its absolute best. Not much left to do with it besides make it flip or slide. It’s going to turn into an ecosystem world. They will start finding ways to compliment the phone by utilizing accessories for it and enhancing ecosystems and use the phone as a branded launch pad to branch off into other electronics such as TVs just as Samsung has been doing. Samsung has an entire At-Home ecosystem which includes appliances that can be controlled via Samsung phones, Tablets, and Galaxy watch. I have a feeling bigger companies without ecosystems such as LG will start looking to do the same. Apple is extremely successful in their more on the go form factor of an ecosystem.. But for the more minor brand leagues, earphones.. smart watches and realistic gaming will be the huge selling points when complimenting their phones.

snippet.textDisplay:
Take a good look at the far more obsolete than the 3.5mm jack supposedly was Lightning port, the pitiful state of USB C audio and the rubbish that is BlueTooth audio and you will have the answer to that question.

Thanks Apple, for removing the 3.5mm jack completely unnecessarily to sell more of your garbage Beats BlueTooth earphones, and, later, Apple AirPods. Thanks Google, Samsung and Co. for aping Apple on removing the 3.5mm jack so you could also sell more of your fourth rate, daily recharge requiring self branded BlueTooth earphones which all sound flatter than a pair of grapes at the bottom of the ocean. (Just like every other pair of BlueTooth earphones.)

It galls me that Apple's brainwashing campaign about the supposed superiority of BlueTooth is so blindly accepted by so many individuals who ought to know better. There was never a need to remove the 3.5mm jack to begin with. However, most of those who are opposed to its removal and cannot be bought with a single pair of wired earbuds that sound like shit and will break within a year would likely not mind the removal of the 3.5mm jack, if it were properly replaced by a wired alternative. A wired alternative like USB C, after USB C audio is improved, and hopefully, after manufacturers dispense with their corporate greed fest and add a second USB C port to their phones enabling charging and listening to audio simultaneously, without requiring an adapter to solve a manufactured problem. While they are at it, perhaps, the manufacturers could add a free USB C to 3.5mm adapter in the boxes of their $1000+ smartphones for those who either do not want to make the switch to USB C audio or are willing to make the switch but would like to continue using the 3.5mm earphones that they already own.
snippet.textOriginal:
Take a good look at the far more obsolete than the 3.5mm jack supposedly was Lightning port, the pitiful state of USB C audio and the rubbish that is BlueTooth audio and you will have the answer to that question. 

Thanks Apple, for removing the 3.5mm jack completely unnecessarily to sell more of your garbage Beats BlueTooth earphones, and, later, Apple AirPods. Thanks Google, Samsung and Co. for aping Apple on removing the 3.5mm jack so you could also sell more of your fourth rate, daily recharge requiring self branded BlueTooth earphones which all sound flatter than a pair of grapes at the bottom of the ocean. (Just like every other pair of BlueTooth earphones.) 

It galls me that Apple's brainwashing campaign about the supposed superiority of BlueTooth is so blindly accepted by so many individuals who ought to know better. There was never a need to remove the 3.5mm jack to begin with. However, most of those who are opposed to its removal and cannot be bought with a single pair of wired earbuds that sound like shit and will break within a year would likely not mind the removal of the 3.5mm jack, if it were properly replaced by a wired alternative. A wired alternative like USB C, after USB C audio is improved, and hopefully, after manufacturers dispense with their corporate greed fest and add a second USB C port to their phones enabling charging and listening to audio simultaneously, without requiring an adapter to solve a manufactured problem. While they are at it, perhaps, the manufacturers could add a free USB C to 3.5mm adapter in the boxes of their $1000+ smartphones for those who either do not want to make the switch to USB C audio or are willing to make the switch but would like to continue using the 3.5mm earphones that they already own.

snippet.textDisplay: The comparison you made between cars and smartphones is not valid. Cars do not look the same and have a lot of leeway when it comes to crafting their aesthetic appeal; they share the same 4 wheel, rectangular form factor, but that’s it. Smartphones have indeed reached an extremely boring, homogeneous aesthetic. That is not to say, as you mentioned, that there isn’t room for improvement anymore; there is - but apparently for under the hood stuff only. Namely, for my money, the two biggest areas in smartphones that still need major improvements are battery life and the cameras. If you don’t consider those, what manufacturers offer nowadays, spec wise, is already more than enough for the consumer. But the user experience is, at least, as important as beefy specs. Motorola bringing the Razr back is a very, very welcomed new stimuli amidst glass-metal-glass rectangular sandwiches. That’s the sort of thinking brands need to embrace.
snippet.textOriginal: The comparison you made between cars and smartphones is not valid. Cars do not look the same and have a lot of leeway when it comes to crafting their aesthetic appeal; they share the same 4 wheel, rectangular form factor, but that’s it. Smartphones have indeed reached an extremely boring, homogeneous aesthetic. That is not to say, as you mentioned, that there isn’t room for improvement anymore; there is - but apparently for under the hood stuff only. Namely, for my money, the two biggest areas in smartphones that still need major improvements are battery life and the cameras. If you don’t consider those, what manufacturers offer nowadays, spec wise, is already more than enough for the consumer. But the user experience is, at least, as important as beefy specs. Motorola bringing the Razr back is a very, very welcomed new stimuli amidst glass-metal-glass rectangular sandwiches. That’s the sort of thinking brands need to embrace.

snippet.textDisplay:
The factor at play here is something in economic terms called "diminishing returns". And it mimics the curve marques shows here... one example is race car design, manufacturers there over time didn't have to spend Loads of money to get their cars to go either very fast in a straight line or straight line quarter mile speed. The more they spend now on improving (ie making cars lighter, more aerodynamic in shape) will require loads more research and development costs only to go a few hundredths or thousandths of a second faster than the previous iteration).

In terms of healthcare and making peole live longer, in the early 1900s it was a case of simply supplying public health sanitation and infrastructure and awareness schemes thereof (hot+cold running water, sewage systems... plus wash your hands+self regularly etc)... nowadays we've got to train brain surgeons and scientists round the world are trying ro cure cancer. And people are hitting peak living ages of 80-90 and only slightly beyond..

In this particular case, Loads more money is being spent by phone designers and manufacturers and devices are being advanced only incrementally. I'd say they (the phone software programmers, and hardware designers and manufacturers) got all the basics ironed out and perfected in terms of both hardware and software round the release of the LG v20 (released October 2016). Since then everything that's been improved upon has only been incremental on existing features (ie more ram, internal storage space, battery capacity) or outright convenience (camera image quality, number of lenses, wireless charging) . Right now I'm just happy with my blackberry keyone black (released mid-end 2017) and my Olympus XZ-1 digital camera thst i bought in 2011, and I don't see myself changing for quite a while yet.

The more they spend now on improving (ie making cars lighter, more aerodynamic in shape) will require loads more research and development costs only to go a few hundredths or thousandths of a second faster than the previous iteration).

In terms of healthcare and making peole live longer, in the early 1900s it was a case of simply supplying public health sanitation and infrastructure and awareness schemes thereof (hot+cold running water, sewage systems... plus wash your hands+self regularly etc)... nowadays we've got to train brain surgeons and scientists round the world are trying ro cure cancer. And people are hitting peak living ages of 80-90 and only slightly beyond..

In this particular case, Loads more money is being spent by phone designers and manufacturers and devices are being advanced only incrementally. I'd say they (the phone software programmers,  and hardware designers and manufacturers) got all the basics ironed out and perfected in terms of both hardware and software round the release of the  LG v20 (released October 2016). Since then everything that's been improved upon has only been incremental on existing features (ie more ram, internal storage space, battery capacity) or outright convenience (camera image quality, number of lenses,  wireless charging) . Right now I'm just happy with my blackberry keyone black (released mid-end 2017) and my Olympus XZ-1 digital camera thst i bought in 2011, and I don't see myself changing for quite a while yet.

snippet.textDisplay:
Xiaomi Redmi K20Pro has a special edition with a crazy (and similar) spec list:
- Snapdragon 855+ processor
- 12 GB of RAM
- 512 GB of internal storage
- 4000 mAh battery
- 6.4" ~ super AMOLED display
- 48MP triple Camera setup
and all these half priced as other competitiors

I think that great specs play a huge role on smart phones today, but they shouldn't be considered as key determinants on the smart phone industry.

snippet.textDisplay:
I dread the day a video like this from a famous content creator is released... While many people are changing phones every 2 years, I've opted to go for a 3-4 years cycle instead and that saved me money.


But if this thinking of "you don't need a new phone every 1-2 years" start to become the norm, these companies will think of other ways to earn back the revenue loss (e.g. increase prices, less freebies, less perks, subscription everything).

snippet.textDisplay: Car and phone is a bad comparison as the absolute best phone on the market costs less than some of the worst used cars on the market. the difference between a $500k and $3K car is extremely obvious. I'd say there's a hell of a lot more to look forward to in the future of cars than phones, I mean society is almost relying on fully autonomous transport to be a thing someday to fix never ending traffic and congestion issues. Phones however the difference between something like a Galaxy S8 and S10 isn't major other than the cameras. They are both highly responsive devices running on a very similar OS. But in conclusion of course every single year they will come fitted with slightly better specs and slightly better cameras, or if the latter isn't possible just add more cameras.

snippet.textDisplay: I have been thinking about this for a while and the reason why you can’t really compare peak phone and peak car is because if you have a car from 1970 and it was in good condition it will be viable. If you had an iPhone 4 you couldn’t run any of the apps coming out nowadays. When iOS 5 came out, iOS 7 came out and iOS 7 made the iPhone 4 barely usable. I think we are pretty close to the point where the latest iPhone will be viable for almost ever. You probably won’t need a phone with a faster processor, better camera and a better battery than the iPhone 11 Pro Max. What do you think?
snippet.textOriginal: I have been thinking about this for a while and the reason why you can’t really compare peak phone and peak car is because if you have a car from 1970 and it was in good condition it will be viable. snippet.textDisplay: Improvements yet to be made. Battery, Functioning foldable screen turning the phone into a full tablet, workstation class CPU, Graphics and storage, full Windows 10X support, automatically switch to TV/Monitor, receiver, mouse, keyboard and other HID's switching to desktop mode when screen peripherals become available. In addition to minor improvements like 8K240fps video All these things are pretty revolutionary and still to come. So no, we are not at peak smartphone yet, far from it.

snippet.textDisplay: To answer simply, yes we are ate at peak Smartphone! Just like back in the day we went from phone to Cellphone, to Smartphone. I think it's time we ditch the "phone" part of the devices and move foward with the "Smart...." part of the device. To make a comparison with your car analogy we will get to peak Car when we don't have a drivers seat in cars anymore, when the day comes when all vehicles drives themselves and there will no real major difference in tech, then it will peak. Cause right now its all about the joy and feeling of driving, what happens when your car just drives you to where you need to go and all you have to do is set the destination and a cloud computer does the math by taking data from all the cars on the road on the same network to plan out the best and most efficient road to get there. Drops you off and drives 3 blocks away to a wireless car charging pad cause the network also knows where to park your car call all you have to do is summon it with an app!
snippet.textOriginal: To answer simply, yes we are ate at peak Smartphone! Just like back in the day we went from phone to Cellphone, to Smartphone. I think it's time we ditch the "phone" part of the devices and move foward with the "Smart...." part of the device. To make a comparison with your car analogy we will get to peak Car when we don't have a drivers seat in cars anymore, when the day comes when all vehicles drives themselves and there will no real major difference in tech, then it will peak. Cause right now its all about the joy and feeling of driving, what happens when your car just drives you to where you need to go and all you have to do is set the destination and a cloud computer does the math by taking data from all the cars on the road on the same network to plan out the best and most efficient road to get there. Drops you off and drives 3 blocks away to a wireless car charging pad cause the network also knows where to park your car call all you have to do is summon it with an app!

snippet.textDisplay: When you compared de Samsung s1 to the s3, the s3 to the s4, the s4 to the s6, the s6 to the s6 edge, the s6 edge to the s8 plus , the  s8 plus to the s10 and the s10 to the s20plus you notice  innovation and new amazing features,  but try to do the same with the iphones line and you'll realize that the biggest difference between the iphone s and the s3, s 6   and s8 or X and 11 Pro max  is the price.

snippet.textOriginal: Are we peak MKBHD?

snippet.textDisplay: I agree that the release of a new generation of phone each year elevates the potential of what you can do with something that takes up a bit of pocket space and it's awesome that you get the sense that people feel less of a need to change a brand new device so frequently just because a shiny new version comes out,... But I also can't help but feel that so much e-waste results from these continual upgrades. It would be interesting to see whether there are any game-changing ideas and developments occurring across the industry to increase the longevity of phones/mobile devices and improve on product sustainability throughout their products' life cycles. If anything, the race for the latest and greatest designs should take into consideration how to reduce environmental footprints as well. (Think Microsoft's carbon-negative approach justified to shareholders as a valid expense because it's more likely to draw consumers and new investment.) The objectivity of your content is refreshing. Question more.

But I also can't help but feel that so much e-waste results from these continual upgrades. It would be interesting to see whether there are any game-changing ideas and developments occurring across the industry to increase the longevity of phones/mobile devices and improve on product sustainability throughout their products' life cycles. If anything, the race for the latest and greatest designs should take into consideration how to reduce environmental footprints as well.
